node.category: Q0: {What is the way things are?}
Q1: {What does Susie do?}
Q1.1: {What does Susie do first?}

node.surface: Susie lifts the lid of the abandoned teapot
and swirls the water.

node.category: Q2: {What does Susie see?}

node.surface: The teabag sloshes against the sides.

node.category: Q3: {What about the tea?}

node.surface: The tea is cold and bitter,

node.category: Q4: {How does Susie feel about this taste?}

node.surface: but Susie doesn't mind

node.category: Q5: {Why doesn't Susie mind?}

node.surface: because her landlady, Mrs Simpson, normally reuses tea bags.

node.category: Q6: {What does the tea normally taste like?}

node.surface: Usually, by the time Susie gets home, the tea mostly tastes of chlorine.

node.category: Q1.2: {What does Susie do second?}

node.surface: As she checks Mrs Simpson's calendar,
Susie rubs the place where the elastic cap from work scrunched all day.

node.category: Q7: {What does Susie see?}

node.surface: A play.

node.category: Q8: {What does Susie feel?}

node.surface: The skin feels puckered and soft, like white and wrinkly fingertips in the bath.

node.category: Q9: {What does that remind Susie of?}

node.surface: Her mother used to read beside the clawfoot bathtub her father imported from England.

node.category: Q10: {What would Susie do then?}

node.surface: Susie—who wasn't a Susie at all then—would tuck her chin over the edge of the tub and listen.

node.category: Q11: {What would happen then?}

node.surface: The water would go cold.

node.category: Q12: {What would happen to Susie?}

node.surface: Her skin would loose and crinkle.

node.category: Q1.3: {What does Susie do third?}
Q1.3.1: {Why is the tea fresh?}

node.surface: Mrs Simpson only makes fresh tea for Mr Johnson next door.

node.category: Q13: {What is special about Mr Johnson's tea?}

node.surface: One cup still contains a moss-smoke slick of whiskey.
Susie wipes the rim of the cup with her sleeve
then pours herself some tea.

node.category: Q14: {What does the whiskey in the tea feel like?}

node.surface: The whiskey is too dilute to be warm

node.category: Q14.1: {Does Susie like the whiskey?}

node.surface: but it's nice to know it's there.

node.category: Q1.4: {What does Susie do fourth after drinking the tea?}

node.surface: In the kitchen window, she sees the red elastic mark below her hairline.

node.category: Q15: {What reaction does Susie have?}

node.surface: She suppresses a sigh

node.category: Q15.1: {What does Susie feel then?}

node.surface: and the air sits heavy in her chest.

node.category: Q16: {What is the reason for the sigh?}
Q17: {How does Susie feel all day?}

node.surface: Susie has a knack for ignoring discomfit.

node.category: Q18: {How does that knack affect her life?}

node.surface: It comes in handy at the factory.

node.category: Q18.1: {What is an example of ignoring discomfit coming in handy?}

node.surface: She felt an itch that morning

node.category: Q19: {What did Susie do about the itch?}

node.surface: but didn't scratch it until after her shift had ended.

node.category: Q18.2: {What is another example of enduring discomfit?}

node.surface: She scrubs her face pink before each shift.

node.category: Q20: {Why is it necessary for Susie to rub her face pink?}

node.surface: A single flake of dead skin can ruin a microchip.

node.category: Q21: {How does that constitute a discomfit?}

node.surface: But the factory is also vacuum-dry

node.category: Q22: {What does Susie do against the dryness?}

node.surface: and she has to moisturise often.

node.category: Q22.1: {What does Susie use as moisturizer?}

node.surface: She can only afford sunflower oil.

node.category: Q23: {What happens when Susie moisturizes with sunflower oil?}

node.surface: For the whole day, she breathes the bitter staleness of cooking oil trapped behind the mask.

node.category: Q24: {How does breathing cooking oil all day feel?}

node.surface: Her tongue is always wool.
In the dust-free factory, her mouth fills with the rat-grey feel of it.

node.category: Q1.5: {What does Susie do after this reminiscence?}

node.surface: She swallows the tea.

node.category: Q63: {What does Susie think about while drinking the tea?}

node.surface: Even if it's a matinee, Mr Johnson will insist on dinner.

node.category: Q64: {Who will pay for the dinner?}

node.surface: Mrs Simpson will pay.

node.category: Q1.6: {What does Susie do sixth?}

node.surface: Susie climbs the stairs to Mrs Simpson's room
and tries the door.

node.category: Q25: {What about the door?}

node.surface: It's locked.

node.category: Q26: {Where does Susie go then?}

node.surface: In the shower room Susie shares with the taxi driver she's never met, she finds hairpins strewn around the sink.

node.category: Q27: {Who do the hair pins belong to?}

node.surface: She's not sure if they are Mrs Simpson's or if the taxi driver has female guests.

node.category: Q27.1: {Can the hair pins belong to female guests?}

node.surface: Guests aren't allowed, of course,
but Susie doesn't know enough about the taxi driver to know if he's the type to flaunt the rules.

node.category: Q1.7: {What does Susie do with the hair pins?}

node.surface: She picks the lock to Mrs Simpson's room.

node.category: Q28: {Has Susie ever been in Mrs Simpson's room before?}

node.surface: Susie's in there every week to clean,

node.category: Q28.1: {When has Susie been in the room?}

node.surface: but only under Mrs Simpson's watchful eye.

node.category: Q29: {Why did Susie only go in there under Mrs Simpson's watchful eye?}

node.surface: Mrs Simpson doesn't trust people.

node.category: Q30: {Who does Mrs Simpson not trust?}

node.surface: She especially doesn't trust immigrants.

node.category: Q31: Susie wonders why Mrs Simpson decided to live with two
Q31.1: {Who are the two immigrants?}

node.surface: (Susie knows the taxi driver is an immigrant

node.category: Q31.1.1: {How does Susie know this?}

node.surface: because Mrs Simpson often says: ‘Oh, I suppose you two are exceptions to the rule',

node.category: Q31.1.1.1: {What is the rule?}

node.surface: the rule being that immigrants impact everything in Mrs Simpson's life and society and the country negatively).
Susie suspects it has something to do with the small rooms and the black mould that spots the wallpaper.
Also, in her interview for the room, Mrs Simpson clearly stated she was looking for someone who works during the day.

node.category: Q32: {why did Mrs Simpson want someone who works in the daytime?}

node.surface: She already had someone who worked during the night.
If she fell and broke her hip at midnight, she needed to know she could rely on the person to be in.

node.category: Q33: {Why does this requirement lead to immigrants living with Mrs Simpson?}

node.surface: Susie thinks this sort of responsibility might put people off.

node.category: Q34: {What does Susie see when she enters the room?}

node.surface: Like the factory, Mrs Simpson's room tries hard to be dust-free and clean,

node.category: Q35: {What does Susie smell?}

node.surface: but it smells of urine.

node.category: Q36: {Why does the room smell of urine?}

node.surface: Susie suspects Mrs Simpson wets the bed and doesn't know.

node.category: Q37: {Does Susie also wet the bed?}

node.surface: Susie can go a whole twelve-hour shift without the bathroom.

node.category: Q38: {How do others deal with the bathroom on shift?}

node.surface: Some of the others use plastic bottles under the conveyor belt and inside their suits.

node.category: Q39: {Can the workers go to the bathroom too?}

node.surface: The company allows for five-minute breaks every three hours,

node.category: Q40: {Why don't the workers go to the bathroom during the break?}

node.surface: but it takes longer than that just to come back through decontamination.

node.category: Q1.8: {What does Susie do eighth (when she is in the room)?}

node.surface: Susie hangs her towel on the radiator, curling her fingers around the warm bars.

node.category: Q41: {What does Susie see?}

node.surface: Along the shelves are glass jars of coloured salts,
and powders,
and liquids.

node.category: Q42: {What does Susie do with the jars?}

node.surface: She opens a jar and inhales.

node.category: Q43: {What does Susie smell?}
Q44: {What does lavender remind Susie of?}

node.surface: She remembers her mother's long dark hair, the thin stripes of grey.

node.category: Q45: {What happens with the lavender flakes?}

node.surface: The flat crystals dissolve into oil that disappears in her dry palms.

node.category: Q46: {What does Susie do with the Lavender flakes?}

node.surface: She sprinkles some into the water.

node.category: Q47: {How many lavender flakes does Susie sprinkle in the water?}

node.surface: Not as many as she would like, but some.

node.category: Q48: {What does Susie do then in the bathroom?}

node.surface: She presses her nose to the clean towels stacked on the shelf.

node.category: Q49: {What does Susie smell?}

node.surface: Washing powder and sunshine.

node.category: Q50: {What does the smell remind Susie of?}

node.surface: Her own towel smells of old socks and the unwashed skin scent that leaks under the door of the taxi driver's room.

node.category: Q51: {What does Susie do then in the bathroom?}

node.surface: She waves her hands through the steam of the running tap.

node.category: Q52: {What does the feeling remind Susie of?}

node.surface: In the factory, the conveyor belts move with constant speed, greased silent.

node.category: Q53: {What happens in the factory?}

node.surface: If she's thinking of something else, like the seamless way her mother poured tea or her father's whiskers above her mother's delicate cups, she will think the belt has stopped.

node.category: Q54: {What will Susie think?}

node.surface: She will think the microchips are standing still

node.category: Q54.1: {What sound does Susie hear?}

node.surface: and the only sound is her circling, oily breath.

node.category: Q55: {What will Susie notice then?}

node.surface: Then she'll hear the sticky peel of a defect from further along the belt

node.category: Q56: {What happens then?}

node.surface: and she'll remember where she is.

node.category: Q1.9: {What does Susie do 9th in the bathroom?}

node.surface: She slips into the water.
She inhales.
She prepares for the lavender memory of her mother's cheek against her forehead.

node.category: Q57: {What does Susie smell?}
But all she smells is chlorine and the wet-dogness of her towel.
Q58: {How does Susie feel about that?}

node.surface: Still, she resolves to enjoy it.

node.category: Q59: {What happens next?}

node.surface: The water slinks past her skin, touches her lips.

node.category: Q60: {What does Susie do with the water on her lips?}

node.surface: She licks them dry.

node.category: Q61: {What does Susie do then?}

node.surface: She imagines her mother's perfectly brewed tea.
She takes a deep breath.

node.category: Q1.10: {What will Susie do later?}

node.surface: After, she will change Mrs Simpson's sheets,

node.category: Q62: {For what reason does Susie do that?}

node.surface: and hopefully, Mrs Simpson will never know.
